fields.summary: As a GH user I would like the Markers to be available on the Component and Assignee views of the Planning Board

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We would like to be able to track technical debt for issues tagged as debt in JIRA.

Similar to the how we use the Sonar Technical Debt Plugin to track debt exposed by static code analyzers and dynamic unit tests.
http://docs.codehaus.org/display/SONAR/Technical+Debt+Plugin

Would like to somehow tag an issue as technical debt (labels or field) and then be able to see the debt metrics calculated and displayed on boards or reports.

We were considering developing a JIRA plugin or gadget (for use in any OpenSocial Container) to call JIRA API and calculate debt. I think it would be better if this was provided by GH.
fields.summary: As a stakeholder I can track technical debt record as issues in JIRA.

fields.description:
When I am in planning board and choose "Project Overview" in the View drop-down menu then the panel on the right hand side shows some useful stats relating to issue status & time estimates. These stats don't describe the full project (i.e. open versions & released versions) but only detail projects that are still open/active (i.e. have not been released).

Is it possible we could show both sets of numbers?

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
4.3 introduced links on the Epic that are available if the Epic has a self-label with its own key.  This is confusing for existing data because no self-label exists.  JC has pointed out that new cards created from that Epic will fix the data (add a label to the Epic).  However, this doesn't alleviate the support issues we face with users.  

It would be nice if we designated an Epic field and Epic issue type in our template and then a background process added missing labels for that type and field.
fields.summary: New Epic self-link not available on existing epics

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
As I understand it, the end dates for charts in Greenhopper are derived from:

# The date selected by the user using the calendar icon in the chart itself
# The release date of the version being viewed
# The latest resolved date in the set of issues being viewed

If the release date of the version being viewed is earlier than the dates where activity occurred, the chart will be displayed with a single day and will not contain meaningful data.

If there's a good way to avoid this situation, it would be helpful to make it so that either a chart with corrected dates or a warning about the problem is always displayed.
fields.summary: Improve handling of start and end dates used for charts

fields.description:
Not sure if this is a bug or "design" issue...

There were a couple tickets that had gotten all the way to our "ready to release" status, and resolution was "Resolved" before we had to reopen them and make additional changes before the release.
They were not re-done (not with a resolution of "resolved") at the time of the release, so they were supposed to be rolled over. When I released the version, these tickets did not move to the next release, even though they weren't done.
I was wondering if may be things are released based on the "resolution date" (what ever that is - saw it as a JQL field...) instead of the actual resolution.

Anyway, I would like re-opened tickets that aren't "resolved" to be moved to the next iteration when I release.
fields.summary: reopened tickets were not moved to next iteration after releasing

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I feel like I could do this prior to the 4.0 upgrade...

When we are doing pre-planning, using the Planning Board in list view, we often have a ticket number. Previously, when you entered the ticket number into the search, it took you to the page on the planning board where you ticket was, and highlighted it, so you could see how it ranked, which was usually near other related tickets you may also want to deal with. You could then drag it to the appropriate place in the backlog, to order your backlog. 
Now, you just see the ticket in the pop-up results box, and can't drag it anywhere. 
You can only open it, and you the backlog rank picker on the ticket page to re-rank your ticket, which is not the greatest tool when you have a big backlog like ours since fewer tickets show up on the "screen".

May be related to GHS-140
fields.summary: Find an individual ticket in its ranking context

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
As an admin, when I release a version from the Planning Board, I would like to see a list of the "unresolved" items that I am being asked to move to another version/do nothing with, so that I can know what I'm moving.  It would be super-great if they were filter results, or some other kinds of list where I could view the full ticket and update them if necessary.

My usual actions are:
1) Try to release the iteration
2) pop up box prompts me about X number of open issues
3) I try a bunch of different searches to track down the items and update them or ensure that I do want to move them
4) Go back and release for real this time.

For some reason, it takes me an inordinate amount of time find the items on my own, even though I would say I'm our most proficient Jira user.
fields.summary: As a GH user I would like to be notified of those cards "not done" when releasing a fixVersion

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
As a scrum master, I would like to see all the issues listed in the task board at once, so that I don't have to "page" through the columns.

When we do 30 day sprints, I find that I have to "page" through columns, even through there is more screen real estate in the given columns. So for regular iterations, I'd like to see all the tickets. Our backlogs are also fix versions, so it might not be practical for that... so a configuration maybe where I could set the number to a max we'd have in the sprint, and it wouldn't freak out (still paginate) if we try to view the backlog in the task board view. (Oh, this is using the "list view", without expansion/without subtasks.)
fields.summary: More items in task board columns

fields.description:
Using greenhopper seems to be causing all of my Jira installation to hang.

Steps to reproduce:
# Select Agile | Planning board from the main menu
# Click on "Unscheduled" in the right project list
## It seems to happen any time I click on a "Project" in the right column.

Note:
The spinning logo next to the "My Issues" check.  This continues until my proxy server indicates that the connection has timed out (couple minutes).

*Lengthy Details*

After this, Jira is hung - will not shut down and will not accept connections.  Connections are not rejected, but Jira does not respond.  Specifically, if I try to connect a browser, it spins waiting for a response from Jira.  If I kill the Jira process on the server (will not shut down gracefully at this point), the proxy server indicates immediately that the connection was terminated.

After bringing Jira back up, all my issues are present and Jira behaves as expected.  Going back to Greenhopper and clicking on a task in the right pane will again cause it to hang up.  Greenhopper seems to work OK as long as I don't click on any of the task boards.

I recently went through the Dragon's Quest for integration and successfully completed all steps.  Due to memory constraints on the machine I am working with, I have turned off Fisheye and Bamboo until I can find another machine to install them on.  This leaves me 1GB of free memory, so I know that system memory is not the issue.

Here is what I have running on the machine:
# Crowd 2.0.3 (crowd directory) Stand Alone
# Jira 4.0.2 War (Tomcat 6.0.24)
# Greenhopper 4.3
# Confluence 3.1.1 Stand Alone

Please help me identify what else may be useful in figuring out what is going on here.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Greenhopper causes a hang

fields.description:
The documentation doesn't make it very clear how start and end dates for charts are determined.  It would be helpful to update the documentation with an explanation and/or diagram.  Here's a summary based on recent conversations with JC that I hope is a good starting point.  

The start and end dates for GreenHopper charts are determined roughly as follows:

   1. Before preparing the chart, issues are filtered as follows:
          * Issues that aren't in a GreenHopper-enabled are excluded
          * Issues that don't have at least one unreleased fix version selected are excluded
   2. The list of versions is created based on the fix version associated with issues included in the filtered list.
   3. The earliest start date is selected from the list of versions.
   4. The latest end date is selected from the list of versions.

The end date for each version is determined by looking at (in order):

   1. The end date configured in the planning board when viewing the version
   2. The release date of the version
   3. Today's date
fields.summary: Clarify how start and end dates for charts are derived in the documentation...

fields.description:
The 'Burnup Chart's legend needs amendment as its labels are currently confusing.

Currently, the legend indicates the following labels:

* *Burndown chart* (which should be *Burnup chart*)

* *Required daily burndown rate* (which should be *Required daily burnup rate*)

This chart relates to a custom field in which the aim is to gain units (for example, 'business value' units) and so the term 'burndown' is not appropriate and is potentially misleading in this context.
fields.summary: The 'Burnup Chart's legend needs amendment as its labels are currently confusing.

fields.description:
This issue was raised from: [https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-53968]

Steps to replicate the problem:
1. In the default context, set the 'Sort By' to 'Due Date' field.
2. On the right panels, click the icon to view issues in Issue Navigator.
3. The issue list won't come up and the reason is that it is using "Due Date" in the search field rather the "Due".

JQL:
{noformat}
project = OpalRIC AND (fixVersion is EMPTY OR fixVersion in unreleasedVersions()) AND assignee = behbooda AND resolution = Unresolved AND status in (Open, Reopened) ORDER BY "Due Date" DESC, key DESC
{noformat}

The correct field used in JIRA for JQL is '*duedate*' instead "Due Date"
fields.summary: Looking at issues that are listed by due date causes a problem in Greenhopper

fields.description:
GH administrators can create custom templates with the same name as the existing 'Default' and 'Scrum' templates.

This is potentially confusing because if a GH administrator goes ahead and does this, there will be two entries in the template selection field that will say either 'Scrum' or 'Default'.

Sure, the GH admin will be able to distinguish which one is which because the custom template has additional links to the right of its name on this page. However, it's confusing nonetheless.

Duplicate name detection and exception handling (which currently exists for custom templates) should be extended across to the existing 'Scrum' or 'Default' templates.
fields.summary: GH administrators can create custom templates with the same name as the existing 'Default' and 'Scrum' templates.

fields.description:
If your JVM region and language are different than your system and/or user preferences, you will see a mixture of languages used for the legends in the chart.  The start and end date control displayed on the chart board will use the system/user preferences.  The legend of the graph will use a different format for the month name, and will use the JVM locale instead.  See below for an example where my user preference was set to French and my JVM was forced to user.region=fi and user.language=FI.

!Picture 3.png!
fields.summary: Chart legend pulls locale from JVM settings rather than user or system settings.

fields.description:
The GreenHopper 4.3 includes possibility to import GreenHopper component to use it in 3rd party plugins (http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/GHS-1917). Actually, this does not work. Even an empty plugin with just component import fails to start.

The plugin descriptor

{code}
<atlassian-plugin key="${project.groupId}.${project.artifactId}" name="${project.artifactId}" plugins-version="2">
<plugin-info>
<description>${project.description}</description>
<version>${project.version}</version>
<vendor name="${project.organization.name}" url="${project.organization.url}" />
</plugin-info>
<component-import key="greenhopper-service">
<interface>com.pyxis.greenhopper.GreenHopper</interface>
</component-import>
</atlassian-plugin>
{code}

The project pom.xml
{code}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/maven-v4_0_0.xsd">

<version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>

<name>Example Company</name>
<url>http://www.example.com/</url>
</organization>

<name>test.plugin</name>
<description>This is the pl.atena.jira.plugins:test.plugin plugin for Atlassian JIRA.</description>
<packaging>atlassian-plugin</packaging>

<version>${jira.version}</version>
<scope>provided</scope>

<dependency>

<artifactId>jira-greenhopper-plugin</artifactId>
<version>4.3</version>
<scope>provided</scope>
</dependency>

<build>

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The start and end date used in drawing the Agile Gadget graphs is derived roughly as follows:

# Before preparing the chart, issues are filtered:
#* Issues that aren't in a GreenHopper-enabled are excluded
#* Issues that don't have at least one unreleased fix version selected are excluded
# The list of versions is created based on the fix version associated with issues included in the filtered list.
# The earliest start date is selected from the list of versions.  
# The latest end date is selected from the list of versions.

The end date for each version is determined by looking at (in order):
# The end date configured in the planning board when viewing the version
# The release date of the version
# Today's date

This can lead to unexpected behaviors, such as when viewing a filter that uses "child" versions.   Since "child" issues are also associated with the "master" version, the end date of the "master" version is included in the calculation.  This makes it difficult to construct cross-project graphs that are targeted to specific "child" versions.

Adding the ability to set an end date manually (or to peg the end date to a specific version) would reduce the confusion.
fields.summary: Add ability to control start and end date for Agile Gadget charts...

So from the post function i trigger workflow action for each sub-task in order to close them. As a result the issue and its sub-task change status correctly in jira, but the Greenhopper does not update. (sub-tasks are still in column Open). 
I noticed that in order to see the changes in GH after the post function was executed i have to go to some other lets say version and then come back. Then i already see the changed subtasks in column Close. 
It seems some how the GH does not refresh properly. 
(At moment i am with GH 4.1)
fields.summary: greenhoper 4.1  does not refresh according to issue status after worklow post function

fields.description:
When we check our burndown chart and its projection, GreenHopper displays the chart based on the latest information. Some of our team members log their work through out the day, while many others log theirs at once before leaving the office. When we check the burndown chart, it can be misleading because we want to check the data, and the projections based on them, logged before today, not including today's entries and times passed since end of yesterday.

I found a request elsewhere on the web that existentially says the same:
http://www.greenpeppersoftware.com/site/posts/list/614.page
fields.summary: Option to display burndown chart as of end of previous day

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
# no matter which end-date you set on a version, the chart always shows an additional day at the end

The reason for this seems to be the fact that the chart assumes that the work done a day lowers the "starting values" for the next day. The effect is that things done on a day (the burndown of that day) is actually reflected on the following day, which is incorrect!
fields.summary: Burndown-Chart shows one more day

fields.description:
We are using JIRA now in a small team (4 or 5 people) with the possibility of expanding it company-wide (which would be 200+).

With the new "starter kit" pricing I decided to evaluate Greenhopper as well. Not sure if we'll use it, but in any case, should we get the 100+ license for JIRA, we are unlikely to want to pay for everyone to use Greenhopper as well, more likely the 25-user option. Most of our users of issue tracking software are very casual, simple users and don't need bells and whistles.

Right now it looks like whatever the license for JIRA (10, 25, 50, 100, 100+), if you buy Greenhopper you have to have the same license. That seems silly, please decouple the licensing so that if most users don't need the extra features, we don't have to pay for them to sit unused.
fields.summary: Decouple greenhopper licensing from JIRA licensing
